snippet.title: Inmates use peanut butter to escape an Alabama jail
snippet.content:
The Alabama peanut butter caper was not the most sophisticated jailbreak, but it did the trick. Some inmates in Walker County Jail in Jasper, Alabama saved peanut butter from their sandwiches and used it like modelling clay to help alter the number above a door that led to the outside. The change made the number resemble the ones above cell doors.Photo: Supplied And so when an inmate demanded that a rookie guard open it, the guard thought he was letting the inmate back into his cell. Instead, on Sunday evening, a dozen inmates walked right through the door to make their escape. "Changing some numbers on the door with peanut butter - that may sound crazy," the county sheriff, James E. Underwood, said at a news conference Monday. "But these people are crazy like a fox."Photo: AP Twelve inmates escaped, and by Tuesday night, all of them had been recaptured. Underwood said it took about eight hours to take the first 11 inmates into custody; the 12th was captured Tuesday around 6.30pm, local time. The inmates who escaped ranged in age from 18 to 30 and were facing charges like disorderly conduct, domestic violence and attempted murder, according to the sheriff's department Facebook page.
With tips and help from the public, most were recaptured in the Jasper area, and at least two were picked up at the Flying J Travel Plaza service area near Interstate 65, officials said.

"We've got some evil people down here," Underwood said. "They scheme all the time to con us and our employees here at the jail. You have to stay on your toes. This is one time we slipped up. I'm not going to make any excuses. It was a human error that caused this to happen." Built in 1998, Walker County Jail holds about 240 inmates and is surrounded by a razor-wire fence. As part of their "well laid out" plan, the sheriff said, the inmates threw their blankets over the wire so they could get over it. Two inmates were cut by razor-wire as they fled; one of those inmates was hospitalised so that he could "have his thumb sewn back on," the sheriff said. The inmates had discarded their orange jumpsuits and took advantage of a "young fellow who hasn't been here very long," the sheriff added. The employee had been monitoring about 140 inmates in the jail's "control area" and had "violated policy," Underwood said. He would not specify how the employee would be disciplined, but he said, "We're going to take care of that matter." Underwood also said civilians outside the jail could be charged with crimes for assisting the escape. New York Times
